When visiting the lovely Central Coast, Cambria in particular, definitely take a stroll on Moonstone Beach. There is a lengthy boardwalk which runs parallel to the beach which is great for leisure, exercise, or just meditating to the rhythmic sounds of the waves. The real experience, however, is walking on the beach. It is unlike anything I've ever experienced on our beaches in Southern California.

The beach is full of what are called "moonstones," and they are abundant. We grabbed a bag full to make an indoor planter. In the dry sand/moonstone, it is very soft and your feet sink in nicely. Where it is wet, it is a little harder on the bare feet, but still a pleasurable experience. The kids could have spent hours picking out the rarest looking rocks of all different colors (red, green, purple, etc).

The beach was relatively empty in mid-December, and not because it was cold. The coast was nice and warm and hardly felt like a week before winter. Of course, in addition to the unique moonstones, the ocean was simply stunning.

Located in the "quaint" town of Cambria, it is a "not so typical" Northern California Beach. What makes this so different is that the beach is compiled of pea-sized and smaller gravel. It is made up of several different types of rocks, including "moonstones," and other polished rocks. These include jade, colored glass and an assortment of other colored and multi-colored rocks. There is plenty of drift wood to choose from and dried out "tubulers." These have taken on many twisted and coiled, flexible shapes. The gravel can be very unstable, since it does not pack down even with the tide. So, if you have hip, knee or ankle problems, the beach is pretty rough going. I have knee and hip problems, so I needed my wife to help stabilize me or help me up the inclines back to the stairs. Also, we found NO direct access to the beach. Moderately steep stairs are the only way up and down at the two beach accesses we found. I toughed both out, and was not sure it was all worth it when we finished each day. I would do it again. It was tough, sometimes hard-going, and always painful.... It was worth it for me. You will have to decide for yourself. The surf was gentle and rolling. Several large rocks are scattered throughout the water. We were lucky two out of three days with the marine layer staying well of shore by 10 AM to 1 PM. A wind-breaker was needed both days. On day three, the coast was "socked in." Typical warmer weather situation. You never know what you will get. We live in the valley about a hour from San Francisco. We never head to the coast without checking live satellite/radar maps to find out the condition of the marine layer, i.e., how thick, how wide and how far inland it reaches. This is what you experience along the California Coast. Your best chance for clear, sunny and warm days occur in Winter months. So plan accordingly if you aren't FROM CA, and you want to enjoy the coast. Just remember that the whole state can experience the affects of the marine layer anytime of the year. Moonstone Beach is one of California's many unique beaches. Mainly sand on the east-coast; many diverse beaches, with some sand on the west. Warm water back east. Water ranges from the 50s in the north to the 70s in SoCal. Enjoy part of "California's Gold."
